awd_titl_txt: CC* Planning: Precision Agriculture and the Community
awd_abstract_narration:
Water shortages in California, Arizona, and Nevada will impact crop yield and agriculture in the region for years to come.  By further advancing farming innovations in Yuma, Arizona along the Colorado River, the prospects of sustainable growth, improved research potential, and new infrastructure collaborations benefit STEM programs, industry, and the community.  Yuma is Arizona’s Salad Bowl.  The continued introduction of specialized networking and collaborations with higher education and K-12 institutions in the area improves the opportunity to plan and implement broadband and networking aligned with the science of agriculture.  The use of technology to improve crop yields, or precision agriculture, is a required step forward in the deployment of cyberinfrastructure in rural communities.

The planning effort to improve networking, connect science-oriented programs, and experiment with homework gap services is led by Sun Corridor Network in collaboration with Yuma’s agricultural research community, community college service and agricultural programs, Yuma’s largest elementary and high school programs, the University of Arizona’s experimental farms and regional academic organization, and the desert agricultural research organization. The Yuma collaboration planning activities will improve community-based cyberinfrastructure models, inform the next generation of agricultural infrastructure, and bridge science, engineering, and technology programs by addressing the complex needs of the business and science of agriculture.  The Yuma Collaboration introduces broadband and infrastructure planning in support of precision agriculture during a period of extreme drought and the impacts of water shortages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: AZ Board of Regents on behalf of Arizona State

por.por_cntn:
A prolonged drought in the West is making the fate of the Colorado River less certain putting Agriculture at risk. Between the months of November and April, 90% of the U.S. and Canada's leafy greens and other vegetables come from Yuma area.

Sun Corridor Network’s (SCN) project built a collaboration for planning specialized network infrastructure needed to leverage modern sensor technologies to help conserve water, improve crop yields, target pesticide use and to reduce or eliminate engagement barriers for middle school and high school science, research, and agriculture programs.

The proposed improvements in network aggregation, the deployment of wireless services on experimental farms, and improved connectivity for researchers, will assist the research and educational community by delivering new and needed cyberinfrastructure with an emphasis on agriculture and STEM educational programs.

Starting in October 2021, the SCN project team met with the following planning collaborators to engage in research and cyberinfrastructure services and opportunities in the Yuma region:

  • Arizona Western College – Department of Agricultural Sciences (AWC)
  • Arizona Western College – Department of Information Technologies
  • University of Arizona – College of Agriculture (UA/CoA)
  • University of Arizona – Information Technologies (UITS)
  • University of Arizona – Yuma Center for Excellence for Desert Agriculture (YCEDA)
  • University of Arizona – Yuma Academic Center (UA/Yuma)
  • Yuma Union School District (Grade 7-12)
  • Yuma One School District (K-6)
  • Smith Farms

Planning and technical discovery meetings followed in Yuma to inform and conduct community and research science driver discovery.  Each site visit included meetings and data collection with project participants in support of defining science drivers, establishing collaborations to inform project implementation options, and how the underlying research needs of the Yuma community may be identified and incorporated into the overall planning process.

Year 2 planning efforts moved to codify and prepare project definitions and cost estimates to improve networking, connect science-oriented programs, and experiment with homework gap services led by SCN in collaboration with Yuma’s agricultural research community, community college service and agricultural programs, Yuma’s largest elementary and high school programs, the University of Arizona’s experimental farms and regional academic organization, and the desert agricultural research organization. The Yuma collaboration planning activities improved community-based cyberinfrastructure models, informed the next generation of agricultural infrastructure, and bridge science, engineering, and technology programs by addressing the complex needs of the business and science of agriculture. The Yuma Collaboration introduced broadband and infrastructure planning in support of precision agriculture during a period of extreme drought and the impacts of water shortages.

The conclusion of the planning grant activities resulted in the collection of data and plans to accomplish the following CI activities:

  • Improve external connectivity between the Yuma agriculture/research community through SCN to Phoenix at 100 Gbps or higher.
  • Improve connectivity between regional research operations (UA/Yuma, YCEDA farms, and AWC.
  • Collaborate with the County of Yuma middle mile fiber projects.  The project was awarded to Allo to build and service fiber in Yuma for farms, residences, and businesses.  The project was funded through a grant from the State of Arizona, Broadband Office.
  • Improve data collection at Yuma research location with added instruments, data collection resources, and alternative infrastructure.
  • Plan and deploy wireless services at the UA and AWC research farm locations (to support IoT devices).
  • Plan and deploy a network aggregation service location in Yuma for SCN.
  • Engage Yuma’s K-12 community in science data infrastructure by planning to deploy data collection devices (e.g., weather stations), collect data via a community repository, introduce K-12 teachers and AWC faculty to data science in support of science education specific to agriculture.

Last Modified: 12/19/2023
Modified by: Derek A Masseth
